group_1.narration: <The ocean.>
<It is said to be the origin of all life on earth.@Its immense presence has remained constant@since time immemorial.>
@<It feels every event, as though each one were@a touch upon one's body.>
<Hence, the ocean may know all three of these events@that relate to it...>

group_1.textLeft: Yachiyo, please feel free to take a look at@this, too.
Yes. It was one of Tsuyu's most beloved@treasures, one she cherished for all her days.
...No. I want to know the truth.
Not just what was told in fairy tales or in that village@legend...but what really happened according to that@girl's memory.

group_1.textRight: Even if you learn the truth, there's no@changing what happened.

group_1.textLeft: Is this...the Voice Between the Waves...?

group_1.narration: [textBlack:<While these three events occurred]@[textBlack:in different places, all them are]@[textBlack:connected to each other as one story.>]
[textBlack:<If the ocean remembered events of the distant past,]@[textBlack:then it would know the story of the incident]@[textBlack:that brought forth this tale...>]
―Diviner―@(I want my voice to reach him...)
―Diviner―@(Every time I speak, I lose yet more of my power@to leave my voice behind...)
―Diviner―@(But even so...@Please, let me put my feelings into this shell.)
[textBlack:<It all began with the memory of]@[textBlack:a Diviner tormented by her tragic love.>]

[textBlack:<She instilled a seashell with]@[textBlack:her tender hope and love for a sailor - a love]@[textBlack:that remained unfulfilled due to her role as a Diviner.]@[textBlack:That shell was swept out to sea, bearing her yearning...>]

group_1.textCenter: Please let it reach him. Please let it help me@overcome my fate...

group_1.narration: <However, that shell, entrusted to deliver@her thoughts to the one she loved, was cast@into the sea in vain. It continued to drift about@the ocean, speaking of her desire to transcend@the circumstances of her birth and duty...>
<Through many days...>
<Evenings...>
<And nights...>
<The shell continued to float through the ocean,>
<tossed and turned by the waves...>
<The shell that drifted for all that time@would go on to connect two girls@of Kamihama's past.>
<One of them was named Tsuyu Mizuna.>
<The other was called Chizuru.>
―Chizuru―@Hey,@who're you?
―Tsuyu―@Word spoke of strange voices in this area.@I thought they may be those of demons, and came to investigate.
―Tsuyu―@The bad harvest that ravages our land is also the work@of those monsters. It's dangerous here. You must leave.
―Chizuru―@Hehe...hahaha!
―Chizuru―@Mizuna's Shamaness is pretty bad at her job if she didn't notice@the Shamaness of the East had breached the barrier.
―Tsuyu―@I can't believe it...you are the same as I?
―Chizuru―@Yep, so you're the one who needs to get outta here.@Sorry, but I'm taking what's mine.
―Tsuyu―@You know what our people are going through now. If we are@both Diviners, then please join forces with me so that we may@bring an end to it.

<In those days, it was said there was a barrier@between East and West Kamihama, with each side@holding great contempt for the other.@Chizuru despised the residents of the castle@like the rest of her people.>
<However, through finding an enchanted seashell@and hearing the voice contained within,@the story of two girls, hailing from either side@of Kamihama, began to unfold...>
―Chizuru―@This voice...!@Who could―?
―Tsuyu―@Quiet.@She's trying to tell us something...
"You and I come from different@places and different positions.@Our relationship could never be accepted here."
"But despite my sorrow, I refuse to hold@any resentment against my clan.@I want to change this village so that@everyone can live freely and happily."
"So if you're still alive, please remember me,@because I'm still waiting for you..."
<The voice and thoughts cast into that shell@had nothing to do with those girls.>
<Even so, to Tsuyu and Chizuru, it did not sound@as though it were someone else's affair.>
<They were two people, separated by a wall,@unable to reach out to each other.@Their people were destitute and starving.@In order to set things right, the land and its people@needed to change.>
<Through one girl's tragic love,@two others lowered their weapons,@and gave each other a small smile.>
<According to modern calendars, it happened@in August. But in those days, it was considered@the seventh month, and by coincidence@close to Tanabata...>
<Thus were the doings in Kamihama,@which presaged the long-sought union of@the East and West.>
